lessons.title: Create Directories

about.what:
The `mkdir` command **creates new directories** (folders). The name stands for **'make directory'**. It's one of the fundamental commands for organizing your filesystem.

Every project, every organization system, every file structure starts with creating directories. Without `mkdir`, you'd have no way to organize files into logical groups.
about.history:
`mkdir` has been part of Unix since the very early days in the 1970s. In the original Unix filesystem, creating directories was actually a complex operation that required special system calls.

Early Unix systems had strict limitations on directory depth and naming. The original Unix filesystem (Version 1) only supported 14-character filenames, and deeply nested directories could cause performance issues on the small computers of the era.

The command has remained remarkably consistent over 50+ years. The same `mkdir projects` command that worked in 1975 still works identically today.

Interestingly, the Windows command `md` (make directory) was inspired by Unix's `mkdir`, though DOS adopted the shorter name to save typing on slow terminals.
about.example:
```bash
# Create a single directory
mkdir projects

# Create multiple directories at once
mkdir docs images videos

# Create nested structure with -p flag
mkdir -p projects/myapp/src/components

# Common workflow: create and navigate
mkdir my-project
cd my-project

# Organize a project structure
mkdir -p src tests docs assets
```
commonUses: **Project setup** - Create directory structure for new projects
**File organization** - Make folders to categorize files by type or topic
**Build systems** - Create output directories for compiled code
**Data management** - Organize data files by date, category, or source

hints: Use 'mkdir' followed by the directory name you want to create
After creating it, use 'ls' to verify the directory exists
Then use 'cat' to view the file inside it

lessons.title: Create Nested Directories

about.what:
The `mkdir -p` flag creates **nested directories** in a single command, automatically creating any missing parent directories along the path.

Without `-p`, you'd need to create each level one at a time:
```bash
mkdir project
cd project
mkdir src
cd src
mkdir components
```

With `-p`, it's just:
```bash
mkdir -p project/src/components
```

The `-p` flag (short for 'parents') is essential for quickly setting up complex directory structures.
about.history:
The `-p` flag was added to `mkdir` in the late 1970s when developers realized that creating nested directory structures was a common task that required too many commands.

Early Unix systems forced you to create each directory level individually, which was tedious for deep hierarchies. The Berkeley Software Distribution (BSD) introduced the `-p` flag to solve this, and it quickly became standard across all Unix variants.

The flag name 'p' comes from 'parents' - it creates parent directories as needed. It also has the useful property of **not erroring** if the directory already exists, making it idempotent (safe to run multiple times).

Today, `mkdir -p` is one of the most common flag combinations, appearing in countless build scripts, installation scripts, and automation tools.
about.example:
```bash
# Create deep nested structure in one command
mkdir -p project/src/components/ui

# Set up a typical project structure
mkdir -p myapp/{src,tests,docs,assets}

# Create date-organized directories
mkdir -p backups/2024/{jan,feb,mar,apr}

# Idempotent - safe to run multiple times
mkdir -p ~/projects/myapp
mkdir -p ~/projects/myapp  # Doesn't error

# Common in build scripts
mkdir -p build/output/dist
```
commonUses: **Quick project setup** - Create entire directory structures in one command
**Build systems** - Ensure output directories exist before compilation
**Installation scripts** - Create config directories that might not exist
**Automated workflows** - Safe directory creation that won't fail if directory exists
**Data pipelines** - Create organized output directories for processed data

hints: This creates all parent directories automatically
Navigate to the deepest directory to find your code

lessons.title: Create Multiple Directories

about.what:
`mkdir` can create **multiple directories** at once by listing them as separate arguments:

```bash
mkdir docs images videos
```

This creates three directories in a single command, which is much faster than running `mkdir` three times.

You can combine this with the `-p` flag to create complex structures:
```bash
mkdir -p project/{src,tests,docs}
```

This uses **brace expansion** (a shell feature) to create `project/src`, `project/tests`, and `project/docs` simultaneously.
about.history:
Multi-argument support in `mkdir` has been present since early Unix. The Unix philosophy emphasized creating tools that could process multiple inputs, and `mkdir` followed this pattern.

The real power came with **brace expansion**, introduced in the C shell (csh) in the late 1970s and later adopted by Bash and other modern shells. Brace expansion lets you generate multiple arguments from a compact pattern.

Before brace expansion, scripts would use loops:
```bash
for dir in src tests docs; do
  mkdir $dir
done
```

With brace expansion:
```bash
mkdir {src,tests,docs}
```

This pattern is now fundamental to shell scripting and interactive command-line work.
commonUses: **Project initialization** - Set up all needed directories at once
**Media organization** - Set up folders for different content types
